Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Research the local wildlife species you intend to photograph and their behaviors. â€¢ Scout the location in advance to identify potential shooting spots and times. â€¢ Pack necessary gear, ensuring you have a telephoto lens suitable for wildlife. â€¢ Check the weather forecast to plan for optimal shooting conditions. â€¢ Prepare to spend extended periods in the field to increase chances of capturing desired moments. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use aperture priority mode to control depth of field when photographing animals in their habitats. â€¢ Utilize shutter priority mode to freeze motion during dynamic wildlife behavior. â€¢ Set ISO to a fixed value (ISO 200) to maintain consistent exposure settings. â€¢ Focus on the animal's eyes to enhance engagement in the photograph. â€¢ Utilize continuous shooting mode to capture multiple frames of fast-moving wildlife. Creative Focus â€¢ Experiment with different angles and perspectives to add interest to your wildlife shots. â€¢ Incorporate the environment into your compositions to tell a story about the animal's habitat. â€¢ Use leading lines to draw the viewerâ€™s eye towards the wildlife subject. â€¢ Capture candid moments that reveal the behavior and interactions of wildlife. â€¢ Consider the use of negative space to emphasize the subject in your images. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/5.6 with ISO 200 fixed, letting the camera set shutter speed to capture a bird in flight. â€¢ Set your camera to shutter priority mode at 1/1000s with ISO 200 fixed, allowing the camera to set aperture to photograph a running deer. â€¢ Capture a close-up shot of a resting animal using aperture priority mode at f/4 with ISO 200 fixed to create a blurred background. â€¢ Photograph a group of animals interacting using shutter priority mode at 1/250s with ISO 200 fixed to freeze the action. â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed to photograph a landscape with wildlife, ensuring both the subject and background are in focus. â€¢ Set shutter priority mode at 1/500s with ISO 200 fixed to capture a bird landing on a branch, letting the camera adjust the aperture. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Experiment with long exposure techniques using a tripod to capture wildlife moving through a scene at dusk, while maintaining ISO 200. â€¢ Create a series of images that document the behavior of a specific animal over a period, focusing on different times of day and settings. DO / DON'T DO â€¢ âœ“ Do be patient and wait for the right moment to capture wildlife. â€¢ âœ“ Do use a tripod to stabilize your shots, especially in low-light conditions. â€¢ âœ“ Do respect wildlife and maintain a safe distance to avoid disturbing them. â€¢ âœ“ Do familiarize yourself with local wildlife laws and regulations regarding photography. â€¢ âœ“ Do keep your gear ready and accessible for spontaneous opportunities. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't approach wildlife too closely, as it may stress or scare them away. â€¢ âœ— Don't use flash photography, as it can startle animals and disrupt their natural behavior. â€¢ âœ— Don't forget to check your camera settings before shooting. â€¢ âœ— Don't ignore the background in your compositions; it can make or break your shot. â€¢ âœ— Don't rush your shots; take your time to observe and compose. Reflection Questions â€¢ What challenges did you face while trying to photograph wildlife, and how did you overcome them? â€¢ How did using priority modes change the way you approached shooting wildlife? â€¢ What did you learn about animal behavior that helped you capture better images? â€¢ How can you improve your patience and observational skills for future wildlife photography sessions?
